messages.subject: Re: Origami translation
messages.msgSnippet: Hello Mr. Robson, Thank you for your offer. What would you have me do? AS I replyed to Mr. Thomas I am new to Yahoo Groups and am just learning my way around.
messages.messageBody:
Hello Mr. Robson, Thank you for your offer. What would you have me do?
AS I replyed to Mr. Thomas I am new to Yahoo Groups and am just learning my way around. Sorry about that. My name is Mark Pederson and I just purchased a wakizashi with NTHK papers that rates this shoto as kanteisho but would like to know more. Thank You.
Sincerely, Mark R. Pederson.

messages.subject: Re: Origami translation
messages.msgSnippet: Thank You Mr. Thomas for your help. I am new to yahoo groups and this is my first post so I do not yet know the proper protocall. My name is Mark Pederson and
messages.messageBody:
Thank You Mr. Thomas for your help. I am new to yahoo groups and this is my first post so I do not yet know the proper protocall. My name is Mark Pederson and I just purchased a 17th. century wakizashi with NTHK papers rating this shoto as kanteisho, the smith being Kaneyoshi of the Mino school @ Gifo. Thats all I know right now but would like to know more. My scanner is not working but I do have pictures. I will try to figure out how to post them. Thanks again.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Barry Thomas" <warlord@...> wrote:
>
> icepick52,
>
> It would be nice to see you sign with your name if you want people to help you!!
>
> You might enjoy Dr Richard Stein's website:
> http://home.earthlink.net/~steinrl/nihonto.htm
>
> and more particularly his origami page:
> http://home.earthlink.net/~steinrl/origami.htm
>
> Another website that offers translation guides for papers is Danny Massey:
> http://www.nihontocraft.com/
>
> His papers translation guide is here:
> http://www.nihontocraft.com/japanese_sword_papers.html
>
> Between these two you should be able to work out most of the translation yourself - and learn something in the process... What you may need further help with is any detailed description aside from the "proforma" language in these guides.
>
> Best regards,
> Barry Thomas
> (Melbourne, Australia)
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Origami translation
messages.msgSnippet: Send an email through to me with a scan off  the papers, I can for the most part translate them all, and if there is something too tough on there, I can send
messages.messageBody:
Send an email through to me with a scan off the papers, I can for the
most part translate them all, and if there is something too tough on
there, I can send to the Gordon, who is usually on here and may see this
post anyway.

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Origami translation
messages.msgSnippet: icepick52, It would be nice to see you sign with your name if you want people to help you!! You might enjoy Dr Richard Stein s website:
messages.messageBody:
icepick52,

It would be nice to see you sign with your name if you want people to help you!!

You might enjoy Dr Richard Stein's website:
http://home.earthlink.net/~steinrl/nihonto.htm

and more particularly his origami page:
http://home.earthlink.net/~steinrl/origami.htm

Another website that offers translation guides for papers is Danny Massey:
http://www.nihontocraft.com/

His papers translation guide is here:
http://www.nihontocraft.com/japanese_sword_papers.html

Between these two you should be able to work out most of the translation yourself - and learn something in the process... What you may need further help with is any detailed description aside from the "proforma" language in these guides.

Best regards,
Barry Thomas
(Melbourne, Australia)


----- Original Message -----
From: icepic52
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, January 18, 2010 3:02 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Origami translation



Hello All, Is there a place that offers a english translation of NTHK papers, Perhaps as a service or a fee ? Thank you.





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.msgSnippet: Try http://www.kyo-to.biz/ They have a pretty good translation department. Use the contact form to engage. Not sure of their fees. Best, Andres ... -- Sent
messages.messageBody:
Try http://www.kyo-to.biz/

They have a pretty good translation department. Use the contact form
to engage. Not sure of their fees.

Best,

Andres
